header: jpmorgan boost fdic-backed bond sale to $6 bln
body:
NEW YORK, Nov 26 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase on Wednesday increased its planned bond sale under a government-backed program to $6 billion from an original $5.5 billion, according to IFR, a Thomson Reuters publication.

The bank sold $5 billion of 3-year fixed-rate notes and $1 billion of 2-year floating-rate notes, said IFR.

The 3-year sales was priced at 99.938 to yield 3.147 percent, or 177.5 basis points over comparable Treasuries.

The 2-year sale was priced at the three-month London Interbank Offer Rate, or Libor, plus 50 basis points. (Reporting by Ciara Linnane; Editing by Tom Hals)

header: update 1-jp morgan cuts price target on five nordic banks
jpmorgan sets guidance on fdic-backed debt -ifr
body:
LONDON, Nov 26 (Reuters) - JPMorgan Chase (JPM.N) has set guidance at mid-swaps plus around 40 basis points on planned three-year euro and sterling denominated bonds under a U.S. Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. (FDIC) guarantee, IFR said on Wednesday.

The benchmark-sized notes will come under the FDIC’s new Temporary Liquidity Guarantee Program.

JPMorgan is managing the triple-A rated deal itself.
